8SXRmwKmbOU.text:
There's no clear winner, because each phone has strengths and weaknesses. Xiaomi benefited when hardware was pushed to the max, e.g. max zoom. When hardware was not the limiting factor though, the Samsung and iPhone pulled ahead depending on the situation.

Personally I think the Samsung was overall the most versatile performer, in large part because it strikes a great balance between solid hardware and refined processing. Also I feel the Samsung usually did best in non-edge case scenarios, i.e. situations most people actually use their camera 95% of the time.
S25 Ultra is very underrated. In fact, it goes toe to toe with two others. And now it's cheaper than others.
The original image captured by Mi
Iphone is the best all rounder, clearly. Shame about iOS tho

The S25 Ultra has some weird issues with the color exposure. Maybe an update could fix it. That being said, the S25 Ultra did well in low light.

I really liked the Xiaomi 15 Ultra's microphone. I like the Xiaomi overall. Maybe the Vivo X200 Ultra and Oppo Find x8 Ultra will compete with the Xiaomi. One thing they could do is lower the exposure and make the 8k video cameras swappable.
All that hardware on the Xiaomi and its just... Mehhhh
Food for the thought, if Xiaomi or Vivo or these Chinese phones are really the best out there, why people doesnt really give af about them? You already know the answer.

With what i was hearing, i thought that Xiaomi would win in all the categories. But guess what? I didn't like it in almost all the occasions. Even at video level, the colors are too warm (his face is yellow). For me, clear winners are Samsung and Iphone. Yeah, Xiaomi's micro is amazing but...would you buy a mobile for its micro? Besides that, sometimes you need to have the noise in your video. I prefer iphone's and samsung's noise cancellation.

OzJLxvGIABc.text:
I switched to this phone and I am coming from the Pixel 3 that unfortunately gave out randomly one morning a little over a month ago. If that phone was working/replacing/fixing it wasn't more than the cost of just buying the same phone then I would still be using it. I instead switched to this phone a couple weeks ago since I do like Pixel phones(the features) and it will be updated until 2030. I don't care to replace my phone if it works so I'm hoping this will last longer than the 5 years my Pixel 3 lasted. I got the Pixel 8 Pro for 350-380$ with the regular model only being 10 dollars less so I opted for this one.

And first impressions, the mic is subpar(at least in Discord, recording app it seemed fine), the phone is too large(Pixel 3 5.5in vs the Pro 8 6.7in so that's very apparent which makes it annoying to use the phone, the weight isn't an issue though) but it is nice for watching YouTube but honestly I would still prefer a smaller sized phone, I like the recording app feature where it condenses what was said and it has speakers labeled but I am only one speaker so I haven't tested that, I have a nice magnetic case for magsafe and I'm enjoying that but haven't tested a car holder so can't say how well it holds up, the front camera is not as good as the Pixel 3 at least in low light conditions(night sight), in the exact same scenario the Pixel 3 night sight front photo was way brighter to where I could clearly see my face, on the 8 Pro I could barely make out my face so it was a major disappointment and the front camera in regular lighting I feel like my face was too defined vs the Pixel 3 had a softer look which I miss, also the lighting it chooses is odd for the front camera, it's way too white or it will flash blue so I have it set to manual control to fix that, I am unsure if somehow I'm doing something wrong or what, for some reason live caption just won't work, and active edge is no longer a feature so that is a bummer, no back finger print sensor like on the Pixel 3 and this in screen one is iffy at best, double back tap is nice for taking screenshots or turning on the brightness, the shortcuts on the lockscreen are nice too, I have mine set to flashlight and mute, the temp feature I have only used it twice but I imagine it being useful(one person has used it to test the sidewalk temp for when they take their pets out), the battery is better but this is a new phone with a bigger battery so duh and I turned off high refresh and high resolution so I'm sure that has helped me. The extra zoom on the camera is nice but I haven't used it much. I would like more control on photos with the camera, I'm not sure what but I feel like something is missing.

Main takeaway, the features I care about or have tested are either the same or worse so I feel like I have a slightly worse phone than I did with my Pixel 3 except this new one has a better battery but it's also more clunky(I don't like big phones, I want to be able to use them one handed with no effort, I WISH they had a proper one handed mode, I hate the one that is used, it just makes it so the top half of your phone goes black, I wish you could make it do that to the side so that it would be brought closer to one side so that reaching across the phone would be easy not just up the phone). The magic eraser, audio erase, video something feature that only the 8 pro has, Gemini and some features like that I haven't used so maybe I would like that a lot more. This makes it seem like I hate the phone, I don't, I just didn't care for an 'upgrade'(this almost doesn't feel like an upgrade) so I might be a little more critical than I normally would be.

Thoughts anyone has about this is welcome or even help with the microphone would be appreciated. If you like the phone or dislike it, I'm curious as to why. Have a great day!

I have had ky Pixel 8 Pro since launch and absolutely love it. There is nothing that I can throw at it that it won't handle smoothly, the camera is out of this world, has decent batty life, feels incredible in the hand, and incredible AI features.

Those AI features alone are a game changer. I can't live without these features, and Samsungs watered down version would still leave me wanting more.

The Pixel Watch 2 is incredibly comfortable and smooth. I don't like the small size and big bezles, the Non-Customizable list view app launcher is annoying, and the tap to pay is not reliable. However, I still find myself wearing it over my Samsung Galaxy Watch 6 Classic due to how comfortable and fast it is.

Thr Pixel Buds are fantastic. Battery life is fantastic (I've never seen the buds below 50%), the sound is great, conversation mode is seamless, and the noise cancelation is good.

Moving over to the Pixel line has be a joy.
